results.title: Ian Botham
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cricketing legends”.
Richie Benaud and Jim Laker examine the cricketing achievements of one of the greatest all-rounders - Ian Botham. A controversial and colourful figure both on and off the field, Botham was a talented player who took some unbelievable catches in the slips and at the time of this programs’ production, was the only cricketer to score 5000 runs and take 300 wickets in Test Matches. Botham played for England and for the counties of Somerset and Worcestershire, making his debut in first-class cricket in the 1977 winning Ashes series. The highlights of Botham’s career are interspersed with an interview between Botham and Benaud.

results.title: Ian's case (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Improving Performance”.
Peter Quarry introduces a 3 step process for discussing poor work performance with staff. Discusses real life examples of common mistakes together with the correct way to counsel staff.

results.title: Ian's case
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Improving Performance”.
Ian works in an art department. His work has become sloppy, he makes long personal phone calls, he drinks and he is constantly late or off work. His supervisor, Hugo, has spoken to him twice previously and now adopts the hard approach. Peter Quarry then assumes the role of supervisor and uses the 3 step approach.

results.title: I.S.O. inter-laboratory apparel flammability trials
results.brief_description: A record of flammability trials carried out by the CSIRO Division of Protein Chemistry in collaboration with the Standards Association of Australia. The fabrics tested covered a spectrum of flammability characteristics and consisted of natural and synthetic fibres and blends of these.

results.title: I.L.O. (International Labour Organization)
results.brief_description: The film shows how the International Labour Organization, established in 1919, continues to bring together the representatives of forty-six member nations to set uniform standards of social welfare for the working people of the world. The carrying out of the policies in mines, mills and merchant shipping from Montreal to Shanghai demonstrates the practicality of international legislation.

results.title: i.d.
results.creator_credit: Sally Hibbin, Parallax Pictures, Metropolis Filmproduktions and Philip Davis
results.brief_description: Philip Davis is probably better known as an actor who has played both bit parts and lead roles in film and television (Secrets and lies, In the name of the father, North Square (TV series), Blue ice) but he has also directed several films including “i.d.”, his debut film. Interestingly, the plot for “i.d.” has a close link to that of a film which Philip Davis starred in five years earlier, “The Firm” (dir. Alan Clarke, 1989) where the central theme focused around English soccer violence and soccer gangs. “i.d.” tells the story of a British police detective, John (Reece Dinsdale) who, along with three other officers, is sent undercover to blend in with a group of fanatical soccer fans. Their main goal is to identify the gang leaders (or “generals”) who perpetrate and orchestrate the violence and the reasons, or the driving force, as to why they do it. Soccer hooliganism has become a part of Saturday life in London, but the police suspect there is far more to it than just obsessed hard-drinking fans cutting loose. To discover what really goes on behind the scenes, John starts hanging out with a local league team, Shadwell Town, and its hooligan followers, going to the matches, joining in the rumbles, and doing a lot of hard drinking. It’s not long before John finds himself becoming more and more a part of this life, that he is behaving like the thugs he is trying to set up, and relationships are beginning to take an unexpected turn. Violent and brutal, “i.d” is a realistic portrayal of those involved in soccer hooliganism and of working class England at the time. Cast also includes Richard Graham, Claire Skinner, Sean Pertwee, Saskia Reeves and Warren Clarke.

results.title: I.A.A.F. track and field events, Helsinki
results.creator_credit: International Amateur Athletic Federation and Guy Butler
results.brief_description: Documentary highlights of the diverse sectors of the Helsinki 1952 Olympic Games ranging from the Opening Ceremony to specific events, ie field, high jump, long jump. Shows respective winners at these events and the lead up to their victory. Silent film with English subtext.

results.title: I. F. Stone's Weekly
results.brief_description: For 19 years, from 1952 when he was outcast from mainstream journalism because of his opposition to the McCarthy witchhunts, investigative reporter, I. F. Stone, produced a weekly newsletter dedicated to unearthing the true facts behind the double-speak and misinformation fed to the media by US Federal politicians. In this documentary made between 1970 and 1973, on the eve of Stone’s retirement, he is shown as an eccentric and entertaining man who, despite his age, energetically pursues the truth behind the American involvement in Vietnam.

results.title: I, toddler
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Southern California Consortium and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Time to grow”.
Investigates the benefits of secure attachment of toddlers to care givers, allowing growing independence in an emotionally secure environment.
